File.Title: Regional and Laminar Organization of Projections From the Presubiculum and Parasubiculum to the Entorhinal Cortex: An Anterograde Tracing Study in the Rat
File.Authors: MARIA CABALLERO-BLEDA AND MENNO P. WITTER

Abstract.S: The regional and laminar organization of the projections from the presubiculum and the parasubiculum to the entorhinal cortex was analyzed in the rat with the anterograde tracer Phaseolus vulgaris-leucoagglutinin (Pl-IA-L).
The projections from the presubiculum were bilateral and confined to layers I11 and I of the medial entorhinal area (MEA).
Both the ipsiand the contralateral projections showed similar distributions and were almost of equal density.

Projections to layer 111 of the entorhinal cortex arose predominantly from superficial layers of the presubiculum, whereas the fibers that reach layer I of the entorhinal cortex appear to originate preferentially from the deep layers of the presubiculum.
These fibers also appeared to innervate weakly layer I1 of MEA.
The parasubiculum distributed projections not only to MEA but also to the lateral entorhinal area (LEA), innervatinglayer I1 selectively.
The innervation of LEA was quite dense and extensive.
Very weak projections from the parasubiculum to the contralateral entorhinal cortex were observed in this study.

The position of the terminal plexus in the entorhinal cortex was determined by the point of origin along both the dorsoventral and transverse or proximodistal axes of the presubiculum and parasubiculum.

Projections from the presubiculum and parasubiculum entered the entorhinal cortex at the level of the injection, or slightly ventral to it, and the main terminal field was always present ventrally to the injection site.
The dorsoventral axis of origin thus corresponded to a similarly oriented axis of termination in the entorhinal cortex.
The distribution in relation to the origin along the transverse axis was more complex, and differences between the presubiculum and parasubiculum were present.
The proximal presubiculum, i.e., the part closest to the subiculum, projected to the most lateral part of MEA and the central part of the presubiculum sent fibers to the most medial part of MEA.
The distal part of the presubiculum, i.e., the part that borders the parasubiculum, projected to the central part of MEA.

Projections from the portion of the parasubiculum directly adjacent to the presubiculum, the so-called proximal parasubiculum, reached medial parts of MEA, and those originating in the central part distributed preferentially to lateral parts of MEA and adjacent medial parts of LEA.
The distal part of the parasubiculum that borders the entorhinal cortex projected mainly to almost the full mediolateral extent of LEA.

The regional and laminar organizations of the projections from the presubiculum and parasubiculum to the entorhinal cortex suggest that information is selectively conveyed not only to different cell layers but also to restricted dorsoventral and mediolateral parts of the entorhinal cortex. r 199s Wiley-Liss, Inc.

Introduction.S: The entorhinal cortxx occupies a key position in the connections from the cortex to the hippocampal formation.

Neurons in the superficial layers I1 and 111 of the entorhinal cortex supply the hippocampal formation with fibers that distribute to all of its subfields, i.e., the dentate gyrus, fields CA3ICA2 and CA1 of the Arnmon's horn, and the subiculum (cf.
Witter et al., '89b).

In both the rat and the monkey there is convincing evidence that cells in layer 11 project almost exclusively to the dentate gyrus and CA3lCA2, whereas cells in layer Ill distribute their axons predominantly to CA1 and the subiculum (Steward and Scoville, '76; Witter and Amaral, '91).

Furthermore, it is clear that most if not all of the cortical inputs to the entorhinal cortex that arise from multimodal association and olfactory cortices are preferentially distributed to the superficial layers 1-111 of the entorhinal cortex (Van Hoesen and Pandya, '75; Van Hoesen et al., '75; Room and Groenewegen, '86; Witter et al., '89a).
The terminal distributions in the entorhinal cortex of several of these cortical inputs show a marked laminar specificity.
Inputs from the olfactory cortices, for example, terminate specifically in layer I (Haberly and Price, '78; Turner et al., '78; Kosel et al., '81; Room et al., '84).

The projections from the parasubiculum show a marked preference for layer I1 and those from the presubiculum and perirhinal cortex selectively distribute in layers I and 111 (Shipley, '75; Swanson and Cowan, '77; Beckstead, '78; Van Hoesen, '82; Amaral et al., '84; Kohler, '85; Room and Groenewegen, '86; Witter et al., '86, '89b).
The presubiculum and parasubiculum differ with respect to the origins of their major inputs (cf.
Van Groen and Wyss, '90a).

This suggests that these two cortical areas supply the entorhinal cortex with functionally different information which may then be channeled through the differential projections of layers I1 and I11 to different subfields of the hippocampal formation.
For this to be true, one must assume specific input-output arrangements to exist in layers I1 and 111 of the entorhinal cortex.
It is therefore of interest to study the synaptic relations between terminating fibers from the presubiculum and parasubiculum and their postsynaptic entorhinal targets.
For this type of analysis detailed knowledge about the topographical organization of these pathways is required.

The most extensive study on the projections from the presubiculum and parasubiculum to the entorhinal cortex in which the sensitive anterograde tracer Phaseolus uulgaris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) was used (Kohler '85) only in part addressed the topographical aspects of these projections.

Since it has been well established that most of the connections of the hippocampal region are topographically organized along the dorsoventral axis, it is of interest to analyse the organization of'the presubiculum and parasubiculum projections to the entorhinal cortex with respect to this topography.
The parasubiculum of the rat may comprise two cytoarchitectonically different subdivisions, areas 49a and 49b, that are differently located along the mediolateral or transverse axis.
Area 49a borders the entorhinal cortex and area 49b borders the presubiculuni (Blackstad, '56; Haug, '76).

Although no such subdivision along the transverse axis of the presubiculum has been described, this should not be taken to imply that no hodological differences along the transverse axis could be present.

For example, in the hippocampal fields CA1 and subiculum, where there are no cytoarchitectonic subdivisions along the transverse axis, hodological differences along this axis are apparent (Ishizuka et id., '90; Witter and Groenewegen, '90, '92; Witter et al., '90; Amaral et al., '91).
Therefore, it is important to compare the distribution of projections that arise from different populations of cells along the transverse axis of both the parasubiculum and the presubiculum.
In the present study, we used PHA-L as tracer, since it allows small, restricted injections to be made that can be reliably delineated.

Emphasis will be placed on the relations between the origin of projections along the dorsoventral and transverse axes of the presubiculum and the parasubiculurn and the location of their terminals in the entorhinal cortex.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Fourteen female Wistar rats (weight 150-200 g; Harlan Centraal Proefdierbedrijf, Zeist, The Netherlands) were used.

They were deeply anesthetized with 1 mlikg body weight of a mixture of ketamine and xylazine (4:3; 1% solution of Ket, Aesco, Boxtel, The Netherlands, and 2% solution of Rompun, Bayer, Brussels, Belgium) and mounted in a stereotaxic frame.

A glass micropipette (tip diameter 10-20 pm) filled with Phaseolus vulgaris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L, Vector, Burlingame, CA, 25 kg/pl in 50 mM Tris-buffered saline, pH 7.4) was placed into the presubiculurn or parasubiculum using coordinates derived from the atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('86).
Iontophoretic injections were made by applying a positive pulsed DC current (7.5 FA; 7 s on/7 s off, for 15 minutes.
Injections were positioned along the dorsoventral axis of the presubiculum and parasubiculum and, at each dorsoventral level, injections were aimed at different transverse positions.
Four animals received single injections of PHA-L.
Ten animals also received injections of the retrogradely transported tracer Fast Blue into the fields CAl/subiculum and dentate gyrus/CA3.

These latter experiments, which will be described in more detail in another report (Caballero Bleda et al., in prep.) were meant to characterize potential postsynaptic targets of presubiculum and parasubiculum fibers in the entorhinal cortex as hippocampal-projecting cells.
After a survival time of 7-9 days the animals received an overdose of sodium pentobarbital (Nembutal, 60 mgikg body weight; Ceva, Paris, France) and were perfused through the ascending aorta.
The four animals with the single PHA-L injections were perfused with saline (100 ml) followed by 500 ml of a phosphate (100 mM) buffered 4% paraformaldehyde, 0.05% glutaraldehyde solution (pH 7.4).
Following postfixation for l h in the same fixative, the brains were stored overnight at 4°C in a solution containing 20% glycerine and 2% dimethyl sulfoxide in 100 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
The brains were cut on a freezing microtome in 40 km thick horizontal sections that were collected in phosphate buffer (100 mM, pH 7.4).
After rinsing (3 x 10 min) in Tris-buffered saline (50 mM Tris and 0.85% NaCl, pH 7.6) with 0.5% Triton X-100 (TBS-Tx; Triton Trademark of Sigma, St.
Louis, MO), the sections were incubated overnight (4°C) in rabbit anti-PHA-L immunoglobulin (1:2,000; Vector, Burlingame, CA) in TBS-Tx.

The next day, the sections were rinsed (3 x 10 min) in TBS-Tx, and incubated for one hour (room temperature) in swine anti-rabbit immunoglobulin in TBS-Tx (150; Nordic Immunochemicals, Tilburg, The Netherlands).

The sections were subsequently rinsed (3 x 10 min) in TBS-Tx and transferred to rabbit peroxidase-antiperoxidase (PAP) in TBS-Tx (1:800; Nordic Immunochemicals, Tilburg, The Netherlands) for 1 hour at room temperature.
Following washes in TrisiHCl, pH 7.6 (3 x 10 min), the sections were incubated for 20 min (room temp.) in a solution containing 5 mg diamino benzidine (DAB) and 3.3 pI HaOz in 10 ml TrisiHCl, pH 7.6.
During the incubations, the sections were kept in gentle agitation on a rotator table.
Finally, the sections were rinsed 3 x 10 minutes in TrisiHCl, mounted on glass slides from a 0.2% gelatine solution in TrisiHCl, and subsequently coverslipped.

The animals that received an additional Fast Blue injection were perfused with saline (100 ml) followed by 500 ml of a fixative containing 4% paraformaldehyde, 0.05% glutaraldehyde, and 15%) picric acid in 100 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
The brain was removed, postfixed for 1 hour, and cut on a vibratome into 200 Fm thick horizontal slices.
Subsequently, selected retrogradely labeled cells were filled with Lucifer Yellow.
After this, the slices were stored for 30 minutes in 0.1% glutaraldehyde in 100 mM phosphate buffer, pH 7.4.

The slices were rinsed in phosphate buffer, cryoprotected by infiltration with 20% glycerine and 2% dimethyl sulfoxide in 100 mM phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, mounted on a freezing microtome on a flat surface of solidly frozen 30% sucrose in phosphate buffer, and cut into 40 km thick sections.
These sections were incubated according to the protocol described above in order to visualize the transported PHA-L.
The borders of the presubiculum and parasubiculum were defined according to cytoarchitectonic criteria described by Haug ('76; cf.
Van Groen and Wyss, '90a).

The injection sites were reconstructed and mapped onto a three-dimensional reconstruction of the hippocampal/ parahippocampal region with the aid of a computer program (PC3D@@, Jandel Scientific, Corte Madera, CA).

Results.S: RESULTS
Nomenclature
To describe the sites of injection in the presubiculum and the parasubiculum, it is necessary to define two axes in these cortical structures (Fig. 1A).
The dorsoventral or longitudinal axis in the rat subicular cortex is almost parallel to the normal dorsoventral axis in the brain.
The transverse axis is oriented perpendicular to the dorsoventral axis.
We employ a proximal (close to the subiculum) to distal (close to the entorhinal cortex) terminology to describe positions along the transverse axis (Fig.
IA).
Within the presubiculum, no further subdivisions are recognized and, therefore, the postsubiculum as described by Van Groen and Wyss ('90b) corresponds to the dorsal part of the present presubiculum.

Since area 29e as differentiated by Haug ('76) is difficult to distinguish in non-counterstained and in faintly cresylviolet stained sections from the experimental series, this part is not further differentiated.

The parasubiculum is described as one cortical area although in most sections, except at extreme dorsal and ventral levels, a differentiation between subdivisions a and b (Haug, '76) can be readily made.
The border between areas a and b is indicated in Figure 1.
In the entorhinal cortex, we define a dorsoventral axis that corresponds to the caudorostral axis as normally used when coronal sections are analysed.
The mediolateral or transverse axis is positioned perpendicular to the dorsoventral axis and runs from the border with the parasubiculum to the border with the perirhinal cortex.
In the present study. the entorhinal cortex is subdivided into a lateral (LEA) and medial (MEA) subdivision according to cytoarchitectonic criteria (cf.
Steward, '76).
Description of anterograde tracing experiments
Fourteen cases with iontophoretic injections of' PHA-L into the presubiculum (n = 7) and parasubiculum (n = 7) were analyzed in the present study.
The position of the injection sites is shown in Figure 1B,C.
The resulting labeling in the entorhinal cortex of six injections in the presubiculum and three injections in the parasubiculum will be documented in detail.
Presuhiculum.

TTE.S: The most dorsal injection in the presubiculum (90103; Fig. 1B) was located in its proximal portion, i.e., abutting the subiculum.
Four injections involved the midportion of the proximodistal extent of the presubiculum, at different dorsoventral levels (90552,90473, 91169,90527; Figs. lB, 2A).
The two injections in the most distal portion of the presubiculum, next to the parasubiculum, were positioned at two different dorsoventral levels (90535, 90532; Figs. lB, 2B).
All injections resulted in clearly labeled projections to the entorhinal cortex.

Fibers could be seen leaving the injection site, traveling through the deep layers of the presubiculum and the parasubiculum into the deep layers of the entorhinal cortex, where they gave rise to a terminal plexus that was virtually confined to layers I11 and I (Fig. 3A,B).
In the entorhinal cortex, the mediolateral position of the terminal plexus and the relative densities in layers I11 and I appeared to be dependent on the location of the injection (see below).
Generally, in the most dorsal section through the entorhinal cortex that showed terminal labeling, the labeling was always confined to layer 111.
In the cases that showed additional labeling in layer I of the entorhinal cortex (see below) this was present only at more ventral levels.
In all cases: we noted an almost equally dense contralateral projection that showed organizational characteristics similar to those of the ipsilateral projection.

Results.S: Proximal injection.

TTE.S: The injection in the proximal part of the presubiculum (90103) mainly involved neurons in the superficial layers (lamina principalis external, whereas only a few cells in the layers deep to the lamina dissecans (the lamina principalis interna) were labeled (Fig. 4).
A dense plexus of PHA-L fibers and varicosities was seen in layer I11 of a small area laterally in MEA and no fibers reached LEA (Figs. 3A, 8A).
A few fibers were observed to extend radially from layer III, forming columns through layer I1 into the deep part of layer I where they branched and had varicosities (Figs. 3A, 4C, 9A).
The labeled plexus in the entorhinal cortex first appeared at a level directly ventral to the injection.
The labeling, that was confined to MEA, increased in density at more ventral levels.

Results.S: Note that in this case, in contrast to all other presubiculum injections, the fibers that left the PHA-L labeled cells did not enter the entorhinal cortex directly.
Instead, they first entered the white matter, from where they coursed through the deep entorhinal layers into the superficial layers (Fig. 4A,B).
Central injections.

TTE.S: Four injections along the dorsoventral axis of the central presubiculum were available (cases 90552, 90473, 91169, 90527; Figs. lB, 2A, 5).
The injections in animals 90552 and 90473 were almost in the same location, and therefore, only the results of the smallest injection (90473) will be described.
The injection in this case mainly involved the superficial layers of the presubiculum, although it extended slightly into the layers deep to the lamina dissecans (Fig. 5.1).
The injection in case 90527 (Fig. 5.3) showed a similar laminar involvement, whereas the injection in case 91169 (Figs.
ZA, 5.2) was confined to the superficial layers.
In all cases, no labeling was present at levels dorsal to the injection.
Labeling first appeared at the level of the injection site, and extended into more ventral levels.
The PHA-L labeled terminal plexus was located in the most medial portion of MEA (Figs. 5,8B).
In the case of the ventral injection (90527, Fig. 5.31, the labeled fiber plexus extended slightly more laterally in MEA than in the other cases (90473,91169; Fig. 5).
Although all three cases showed the densest terminal labeling in layer 111, some additional labeling of branched varicose fibers in layer I and of a few radial fibers in layer I1 was observed.
The density of layer I labeling differed between the three cases.
Labeling in layer I was almost absent in case 91169 that had the injection confined to the superficial layers of the presubiculum.

In case of the injections in experiments 90473 and 90527, in which the injection showed additional minor involvement of the deep layers, the density of labeling in layer I was increased compared to that seen in case 91169.

Results.S: Distal injections.

TTE.S: Injections of PHA-L in two different dorsoventral levels (90535, 90532; Figs. lB, 2B, 6) of the distal presubiculum, i.e., abutting the parasubiculum, gave rise to similar labeling patterns in the entorhinal cortex that differed from the patterns described above.
In both cases, the majority of labeled cells were located in the superficial layers of the presubiculum (Fig.
ZB), and no cells were labeled in the parasubiculum.
A very dense plexus of labeled fibers and varicosities was present in the central part of MEA, avoiding the most medial and lateral portions of this cortical area (Figs. 6, 8 0 .
At the level of the injection, the density of labeled fibers in the termination area appeared to be low, predominantly being present in layer 111 (Fig. 6.1B,6.2Cj.
More ventrally, the density of the labeled plexus in layer I11 increased.
No labeling was present in the entorhinal cortex at levels dorsal to the injection site.
The deep portion of the molecular layer also contained a large number of labeled fibers with varicosities (Figs. 3B, 9A).
A columnar pattern of radial fibers with varicosities in layer I1 was clearly present in these two cases (Fig. 6).

Results.S: Parasubitulum.

TTE.S: Two injections in the parasubiculum were confined to the proximal half, i.e., subarea b, and involved clearly different dorsoventral levels (90585; 90790; Figs. lC, 2C).
Two large injections (91016 and 91 150; Figs.
lC, 2D) in the central portion were available for analysis.
The injection sites of these two cases overlapped almost completely.
In animal 91150, the longitudinal extent of the injection site covered about half the dorsoventral axis of the parasubiculum.
Three injections (91151, 91177, 90779) were confined to the distal part of the parasubiculum, i.e., subarea a (Figs. lC, 2E).

The dorsoventral level of the most dorsal of these injections (91151) was similar to that of the proximal injection in case 90790, and showed overlap with the ventrally adjacent injection in case 91177.
The most ventral injection in subarea a was made in case 90779.
All injections resulted in a clearly labeled projection to the entorhinal cortex.
Fibers left the injection site and traveled laterally into layers 111 and IV of the entorhinal cortex.
In none of the cases we observed fibers that coursed through the underlying white matter before entering the entorhinal cortex (Fig. 7).

In all these experiments, the terminal plexus in the entorhinal cortex was confined to layer I1 (Figs. 3C, 7) although occasionally fibers extended into the deep part of the molecular layer (Fig. 9B).

Results.S: As following presubiculum injections, we noted that the mediolateral position of the terminal plexus of the parasubiculum projections strongly depended on the site of the injection (see below).
In contrast to the presubiculum projections, contralateral parasubiculum projections were very scarce.
Proximal injections.

TTE.S: Restricted injections of PHA-L in the proximal parasubiculum in two cases (90585; 90790; Figs. lC, 2C, 7.1B) resulted in almost similar patterns of labeling along the transverse axis of the entorhinal cortex.

Following the more ventral injection (907901, placed approximately midway the longitudinal axis of the parasubiculum, a dense plexus of fibers and varicosities was present, ctinfined to a small area in the most medial portion of layer I1 of MEA (Figs. 7.1, 8D).

Results.S: This terminal plexus was only present at levels ventral to the injection site.
The injection site in case 90585 involved a more dorsal part of the parasubiculum, resulting in labeling in the entorhinal cortex in a more dorsal position (not illustrated).
However, the mediolateral position of the terminal plexus was similar to that seen in case 90790.
Central injections.

TTE.S: In two cases, the injections involved the central portion of the parasubiculum and they showed almost complete overlap (91016; 91150; Figs. lC, 2D, 7.2B).

In case 91150, the labeled terminal fiber plexus was located laterally in the entorhinal cortex, involving the central and lateral portions of layer I1 of MEA and the directly adjacent part of LEA (Figs. 7, 8E).

Results.S: Like in previous cases, the labeling in layer I1 was only present in levels ventral to the level of the injection.
Distal injections.

TTE.S: Three injections confined to the distal part of the parasubiculum, at different dorsoventral levels were available for analysis (91151, 91177, 90779; Figs. lC, 2E, 7.31.
In these cases, the labeling in layer I1 of the entorhinal cortex was not different with respect to the medial-to-lateral position.
Therefore, we will illustrate the results of case 91151, since this injection was positioned almost at the same dorsoventral axis as the other two cases.

The distribution of labeling in the entorhinal cortex in case 91 151 provides additional evidence for the marked preference of the projections from the parasubiculum for layer I1 of the entorhinal cortex (Figs. 2, 3C, 7.3, 8F).
In sections at the level of the injection site, weak labeling was present in layer I1 of LEA, continuing into the adjacent most lateral portion of MEA (Fig. 7.3B).
Ventral to the injection site, a very dense plexus of PHA-L labeled fibers and varicosities exclusively appeared in layer I1 of LEA (Fig. 7.3C,D).

In sections taken through ventral levels of the entorhinal cortex, at the level where LEA takes its largest dimensions, the labeled plexus avoided the typical layer of clustered layer 11 cells and was confined to the most superficial part of layer I11 (layer IIb according to Haug, '76; Fig. 7.3E, 8F).

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
In the present study the regional and laminar organization of the projections from the presubiculum and the parasubiculum to the entorhinal cortex was analysed in the rat.
Both subicular cortices projected to the superficial layers of the entorhinal cortex, but they differed markedly with respect to their precise terminal distribution.
Projections from the presubiculum were confined to MEA and distributed bilaterally.
The contralateral projection was almost equal in density and distributed similarly to that found ipsilaterally (cf.
Kohler, '85).
Projections from the parasubiculum to the contralateral entorhinal area were weak.
This latter finding is in line with previous reports in which a weak projection from the parasubiculum to the contralateral MEA has been described (Kohler, '85; Van Groen and Wyss, '90a).
The parasubiculum projects not only to MEA but also to LEA.
The innervation of LEA appeared quite dense and extensive, which stands in contrast with the data of Kiihler ('85) who referred to this projection as weak and not particularly widespread.
Our results corroborate the presence of clear differences in the laminar distribution between the presubiculum and parasubiculum projections (Kohler, '85; Van Groen and Wyss, '90a,b).
Fibers from the parasubiculum selectively terminate in layer 11.
The projections to the lateral part of LEA excepted, we did not observe termination in either layers I11 or the deeper layers rV-VI.
In the lateral part of LEA, parasubicular fibers distributed mainly to the most superficial part of layer 111, directly deep to a narrow cell-free zone that separates layer I1 from layer 111.

This portion of layer I11 is characterized by the presence of many medium-sized darkly staining cells, and is considered by some authors to represent a deep part of layer 11, instead of formingpart of layer 111 (Haug, '76; Krettek and Price, '77).
In view of the consistent distribution of parasubicular projections to layer 11, the present data support this notion.
Projections from the presubiculum preferentially target layer 111 and to a lesser extent layer I.
In one experiment, in which only the superficial layers of the presubiculum were involved in the injection, we noted only a very weak projection to layer I.
In other cases, which showed some additional involvement of cells in the layers deep to the lamina dissecans, a moderate projection to layer I was labeled in addition to the layer I11 projection.
We therefore conclude that the projections to layer I11 of the entorhinal cortex arise predominantly from the superficial layers of the presubiculum.
The presubicular fibers that distribute to layer I of the entorhinal cortex originate most probably from the deep layers of the presubiculum.
These fibers traverse layer I1 of the entorhinal cortex on their way to layer I and they always show varicosities in layer 11.
This may imply that fibers from the presubiculum do innervate, be it weakly, cells in layer 11.

Since. in contrast, the parasubiculum appears to selectively innervate layer 11, the presubiculum and parasubiculum may thus differ not only in laminar preference of their respective entorhinal projections, but also in the specificity with which this distinctive laminar distribution is maintained.
Whether such is the case has been subject for further study (Caballero-Bleda et al., in prep.).

The main finding of the present study is that the position of the terminal field in the entorhinal cortex of fibers from the presubiculum and the parasubiculum is determined by the point of origin along both the proximodistal and the dorsoventral axes of these cortical areas.
We observed that, on the one hand, the proximodistal position of the origm determined the mediolateral location of the terminal plexus in the entorhinal cortex.
On the other hand, the dorsoventral position of the origin appeared to determine the dorsoventral level of entorhinal cortex that contained the main terminal field.

With respect to this dorsoventral topography, we observed both in the presubiculum and the parasubiculum that projections to the entorhinal cortex never distribute to entorhinal levels dorsal to that of the injection.
This organizational feature may explain why we have not observed any projection to the most dorsal part of the entorhinal cortex in our experiments.
We infer that we should have injected the most dorsal portions of both subicular cortices in order to label that projection.
Organization of presubicular projections

Regarding the projections from the presubiculum, our findings appear to he in contrast with the earlier conclusions obtained in the rat (Kohler, '851, the cat (Room and Groenewegen, '86), and the monkey (Amaral et al., '84).
In these studies, it was reported that dorsal portions of the presubiculum project to lateral parts of MEA, whereas ventral portions of the presubiculum project to medial parts of MEA.
Rather, we found a relationship between the proximodistal origin of the projection and the mediolateral terminal distribution.

First, we noted that projections that originate from different dorsoventral levels of the presubiculum hut from a similar proximodistal position, distribute to a comparable location along the mediolateral axis of the entorhinal cortex.
The only difference noted between the respective terminal distributions was that the terminal fields in the entorhinal cortex differ with respect to their dorsoventral position.

Consistently, we observed that projections to the entorhinal cortex originating in proximal, central or distal portions of the same dorsoventral level of the presubiculum reach the same dorsoventral level of the entorhinal cortex.
However, in such cases the terminal distributions are different from each other regarding their mediolateral position.

An intruiging "irregularity" in the topography of the presubicular projections is that the proximal presubiculum projects to the most lateral part of MEA and the central part of the presubiculum projects to the most medial part of MEA.
Surprisingly, the distal part of the presubiculum projects to the central part of MEA.

Therefore, within the presubiculum a differentiation between proximal and central parts that give rise to topographically organized projections to the most lateral and medial parts of the medial entorhinal cortex respectively, and a distal part that selectively innervates the central zone of the medial entorhinal cortex can be made.
However, we have not been able to selectively inject the distal part of the ventral presubiculum.
Therefore, we cannot be sure that this hodologically defined distal part of the presubiculum continues along the full dorsoventral extent of the presubiculum.

This might be of interest since from a comparison of Figure 8 of Haug ('76) with our Figure 1, it appears that the area that is involved in all the distally placed injections in the presubiculum coincides with area 29e.

Although this cortical area has quite some chemoarchitectonic as well as hodological aspects in common with the presubiculum, it also has some connectional differences that have lead Haug ('76) to separate it from the presubiculum.
Organization of parasubicular projections

Although the general organization of the entorhinal afferents from the parasubiculum is comparable to those from the presubiculum, the present data also point to a major difference between the presubiculum and parasubiculum.

Projections from the proximal portion of the parasubiculum reach medial parts of MEA, and those originating in the central part distribute preferentially to lateral parts of MEA and the adjacent most medial parts of LEA.
The distal part of the parasubiculum appears to send its fibers mainly to virtually the full mediolateral extent of LEA.

Thus, the projections from the parasubiculum to the entorhinal cortex show a topographical organization in which a proximodistal gradient in the parasubiculum is reflected onto a mediolateral gradient in the entorhinal cortex.
This organization is inverted compared to the organization of the projections from the proximal and middle parts of the presubiculurn (see above).
Based on cytoarchitectonic and chemoarchitectonic criteria the parasubiculum of the rat has been subdivided into two areas (Blackstad, '56; Haug, '76).
Areas a and b, as they are generally described, each represent approximately half of the proximodistal extent of the parasubiculum.
Our findings could be taken to support a division of the parasubiculum into two hodologically distinct areas.
The injections that involve either the proximal or distal extremes of the two subdivisions clearly show a difference with respect to the distribution of entorhinal projections.

Since the entire proximodistal extent of the parasubiculum distributes fibers to the complete mediolateral extent of the entorhinal cortex, one could assume that each of the two parasubicular divisions project to approximately half of the mediolateral extent of the entorhinal cortex.

Consistent mith this assumption, we observed that injections in the mid-portion of the parasubiculum, involving adjacent portions of both subfields a and b, result in labeling in adjacent parts of both terminal fields in the entorhinal cortex.
Functional implications

The apparent laminar differences between the projections from the presubiculum and the parasubiculum suggest that layers I1 and 111 of the entorhinal cortex, giving rise to different components of the perforant pathway, may receive functionally different inputs.
This will be addressed in more detail in a forthcoming paper (Caballero-Bleda et al., in prep.).

The specific topography of the projections from both the presubiculum and the parasubiculum to the entorhinal cortex suggest that through each of these pathways information is selectively conveyed to different dorsoventral and mediolateral parts of the entorhinal cortex.

There is evidence that the most dorsal part of the presubiculum receives visual input, either directly from primary visual cortex, or by way of a relay through the retrosplenial cortex (Vogt and Miller, '83).
Moreover, the dorsal presubiculum is characterized by the presence of so-called head direction cells (Taube et al., '90).

Whether comparable differences exist between dorsal and ventral parts of the parasubiculum, and whether different proximodistal parts of both the presubiculum and the parasubiculum transmit functionally different information to restricted cell populations in the entorhinal cortex, needs further investigation.

The possible presence of a selective distribution of information over the mediolateral axis of the entorhinal cortex is of interest in the light of the topographical organization of the origin of the perforant pathway along this entorhinal axis (cf.
Witter et al., '86, '89b).
